description.narrative: To promote an integrated landscape approach to managing wildlife resources, carbon and ecosystem services in the face of climate change in the protected areas and community lands of the Mid to Lower Zambezi Regions of Zimbabwe.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
Mandatory Indicator 1: Number of people benefitting in the project area from CBWM, SFM, and SLM (f/m) (IRRF Indicator 1.3.2a
Indicator 2: Extent to which legislation and institutional frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems: - Updated Wildlife Policy; - Updated Parks and Wildlife Act; - Updated Communal Land Forest Produce Act - Official National Anti-Poaching Strategy
Indicator 3: Populations of flagship species in the project area: - Lion - Elephant - Buffalo
Indicator 4: Number of individuals of flagship species poached annually in the project area: - Lion - Elephant - Buffalo
Indicator 5: Capacity of National Enforcement Agencies to control IWT (UNDP
Indicator 6: Results of IWT law enforcement at national level: - annual number seizures; - annual number of arrests; - annual number of successful prosecutions on poaching and IWT
Indicator 7: Total area under improved CBWM in the project area (established CWC with implemented Wildlife Adaptive Management plans)
Indicator 8: METT score for targeted PAs: 334,500 ha. - Mana Pools NP: - Charara SA - Hurungwe SA - Sapi SA - Chewore SA - Dande SA - Doma SA
Indicator 9: Results of IWT law enforcement in the project area: - annual intensity of patrolling (inspector/days); - annual number seizures - annual number of arrests; - annual number of successful prosecutions on poaching and IWT
Indicator 10: Average annual revenue from CBWM, SFM and SLM per target CWC, $US. - Pfundundu - Mukwichi - Mbire North - Karinyanga - Kanyurira/Masoka - Mavhuradonha Indicator 11: Total area of restored woodlands, ha.
Indicator 12: Total volume of CO2 mitigated in the project area (tCO2eq).
Indicator 13: Number of national and district development plans that address biodiversity and ecosystem management and climate risk management
Indicator 14: Number of the lessons on IWT control and CBNRM learned

Outcome 1. Increased national capacity for IWT control, and integrated wildlife and woodland management
2019 Target: - Review at least two of the following acts and policies; Parks and Wildlife Act; Wildlife Policy; and the development of Human Wildlife Conflict Policy, Communal Land Forest Produce Act and the Forest Act. 2019 Target: - Facilitate transboundary dialogue process between Zimbabwe, Zambia and Mozambique and finalise drafting of the Lower Zambezi-Mana Pools TFCA MoU and ZIMOZA Agreement.
Outcome 2. Improved capacity of PA network and CAMPFIRE Wildlife Conservancies to protect globally significant biodiversity of the mid-lower Zambezi region over a total area of 1,616,900 ha
2019 Target: - Resuscitation of 40 Environmental Sub Committees (ESC), 3 Environmental Committees in Hurungwe, Mbire and Muzarabani Districts.
OUTCOME 3 Increased area under sustainable management and increased benefits for local communities from CBWM, SFM and SLM in established CWCs
2019 Target: - Support establishment of 3 nurseries and drilling of 10 boreholes in 3 CWCs. 2019 Target: - Initiation of at least 3 livelihoods enhancement activities through the Small Grants mechanism
OUTCOME 4 Lessons learned by the project through participatory M&E and gender mainstreaming are used nationally and internationally
2019 TARGET: Participate in GWP meetings and national meetings for knowledge exchange including tourism and wildlife economy-related meetings
PROJECT MANAGEMENT SUPPORT
2019 TARGET: 3 Project Board and Technical Committees meetings

2019 Target: - Review at least two of the following acts and policies; Parks and Wildlife Act; Wildlife Policy; and the development of Human Wildlife Conflict Policy, Communal Land Forest Produce Act and the Forest Act.
Workshops to identify gaps in the Parks and Wildlife Act, Forest Act and Communal Land Forest Produce Act were conducted. The following were identified as key gaps in the Parks and Wildlife Act: -o There is no clear offence on possession of cyanide o There is need to harmonize Acts. Absence of harmonized legislation (EMA, Forestry, Zimbabwe Parks) on hazardous substances Gaps that exists in the forest legislations (Forest Act and Communal Land Forest Produce Act). The following were identified: - o The two pieces of legislation lack Sustainable Forest Management principles. o Commercialization of forest produce should be included in the Act. Communities need to realize value of the forests for them to be effectively involved in the management of the forests. o Devolution in the management of the resource - communities should be actively involved in the management of the forests. Currently the state controls management of forests with little to no power by the communities, who are the resource users. ZPWMA started consultation processes on wildlife policy. A number of key stakeholders in the wildlife sector were consulted. Consultative Workshops for the development of the Human and Wildlife Conflict Policy were held with key stakeholders being consulted.
2019 Target: - Facilitate transboundary dialogue process between Zimbabwe, Zambia and Mozambique and finalise drafting of the Lower Zambezi-Mana Pools TFCA MoU and ZIMOZA Agreement.
A meeting to finalise the ZIMOZA and Lower Zambezi Mana Pools TFCA Agreements was held. During the meeting inputs from Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe were incorporated into the agreements and revised copies were to be sent to partner countries for review and confirmation.
2019 Target: - Resuscitation of 40 Environmental Sub Committees (ESC), 3 Environmental Committees in Hurungwe, Mbire and Muzarabani Districts. 70 Environmental Sub-Committees (ESCs) in the three districts were resuscitated. 3 Environmental committees were established in the three districts
2019 Target: - Support establishment of 3 nurseries and drilling of 10 boreholes in 3 CWCs. Procurement process was completed.
2019 Target: - Initiation of at least 3 livelihoods enhancement activities through the Small Grants mechanism 2 NGOs signed grant agreements with UNDP to implement livelihoods activities in the 3 districts
2019 TARGET: Participate in GWP meetings and national meetings for knowledge exchange including tourism and wildlife economy-related meetings The project supported some project staff and community representatives to attend the African Wildlife Economy Summit held in Victoria Falls. The Summit provided a platform for exchange of lessons and experiences between the Zambezi Valley Biodiversity Project and other conservation programmes in Africa on community participation and beneficiation in the African Wildlife Economy
2019 TARGET: Project Board and Technical Committees meetings 3 Project technical committee meeting were conducted and 2 board meetings.

Outcome 1. Outcome 2. OUTCOME 3 Increased area under sustainable management and increased benefits for local communities from CBWM, SFM and SLM in established CWCs 2021 Target: - Support the establishment of 2 nurseries and drilling of 3 boreholes in 3 CWCs. 2021 Target: - Initiation of at least 2 livelihood enhancement projects through the Small Grants mechanism

Outcome 1. Increased national capacity for IWT control, and integrated wildlife and woodland management 2021 Target: - Conclude at least 2 drafts of the following acts and policies; Parks and Wildlife Act; Wildlife Policy; Human-Wildlife Conflict Management Policy, Communal Land Forest Produce Act; and the Forest Act. • The Parks and Wildlife Act Chapter 20:14 act is being reviewed to align it to the new Constitution and incorporate new and emerging issues. A consultative workshop was held at Cresta Oasis Hotel on the 5th of May 2021. The purpose of the workshop was to present the proposed amendments to various stakeholders from the Northern Region and receive their views and comments • The project is finalising procurement of a consultant to draft the Wildlife Policy.
2021 Target: - Establish One Multi-Agency Wildlife Crime Prevention Unit to ensure strong inter-agency collaboration to fight IWT and forest crimes • A Multi-Agency Unit (MAU) was established at Chinhoyi to cover the Mashonaland West region. A Committee was set up to draft Standard Operating Procedures (SoP), Terms of Reference (ToR) and a Work Plan for the MAU. The project procured field equipment for ZPWMA field rangers and for the Multi Agency Unit staff. The equipment includes sleeping bags, shirts, gas canisters, and handcuffs.
2021 Target: - 2,000 beneficiaries are involved in awareness campaign targeting IWT, deforestation and climate adaptation/mitigation issues in the project areas • The Zimbabwe Environmental Law Association (ZELA) was awarded a grant of US$25,000.00 in 2020 for an awareness project that will be implemented in Mbire and Muzarabani from February 2021 to January 2022. • The Zimbabwe Environmental Law Association (ZELA) trained 80 students (40 females and 40 males) from four secondary schools on environmental E-Law societies in Mbire, Wards 1, 2, 4, and 12 from 7-12 June 2021. • ZELA carried out open house discussions on Illegal Wildlife Trade, deforestation and climate change adaptation and mitigation involving community members, Parks and Wildlife Authority, Forestry Commission and Mbire Rural District Council. The event was attended by 194 participants (29 females and 165 males).
Outcome 2. Improved capacity of PA network and CAMPFIRE Wildlife Conservancies to protect globally significant biodiversity of the mid-lower Zambezi region over a total area of 1,616,900 ha 2021 Target: - Finalise migration of Zambezi Valley radio communication system from analogue to digital to enhance communication by rangers during patrols. • Zimbabwe Parks and Wildlife Management Authority (ZPWMA) finalized installation of radio equipment needed to migrate communication system from analog to digital in Zambezi Valley, however the system is not yet fully functioning to the expected levels. 2021 Target- Drilling of 11 boreholes for wildlife water provision. • The project facilitated drilling of 10 boreholes in Mbire (5) and Hurungwe (5) and these will provide water for communities, wildlife, and tree nurseries at Mushumbi and Chitindiva. 2021 Target: - Construction of 3 pickets in the protected area to enhance anti-poaching activities. • Construction of 1 picket commenced and the builders are currently fitting electrical and pumping materials.
OUTCOME 3 Increased area under sustainable management and increased benefits for local communities from CBWM, SFM and SLM in established CWCs 2021 Target: - Support the establishment of 2 nurseries and drilling of 3 boreholes in 3 CWCs. • Construction of the 3 nurseries was completed. Two out of the 3 boreholes were drilled at nursery sites in Mbire and Hurungwe districts. The nurseries produced 68,752 seedlings during the year. 2021 Target: - Initiation of at least 2 livelihood enhancement projects through the Small Grants mechanism • The project initiated 2 small grants project covering Hurungwe district. Biotechnology Trust Zimbabwe (BTZ) started construction of a biogas-powered tobacco curing barn in Nyamakate, Ward 7 Hurungwe. BTZ also conducted training workshop on renewable energy, sustainable development and environmental management in Ward 7 Nyamakate that was attended by 33 farmers, (9 females and 24 males). Community Technology Development Organisation (CTDO) drilled three boreholes and motorised two out of the three boreholes with solar powered pumps in Hurungwe District. CTDO finalized the establishment of two nutrition gardens in Hurungwe Wards 7 and 8. Water pipelines were connected from the solarized boreholes that were drilled by the project. The nutrition garden in Ward 7 is one hectare in size and the one in Ward 8 is 1.2 hectares. The gardens support a total of 72 beneficiaries (54 females and 18 male).
OUTCOME 4 Lessons learned by the project through participatory M&E and gender mainstreaming are used nationally and internationally 2021 Target: 2 Lessons learned from the project are shared with national and international conservation programmes, including GWP The project shared a lesson with GWP partners on Preparing for all Eventualities during Surveys - Lessons from Zimbabwe.
Major issues highlighted included: - • Ensure that there is a clear line of command and guidance on communicating emergencies. • There is need to prepare for all possible eventualities during development of terms of reference. • In case of disaster, it should be clear who communicates or handles the media. • Even with emergency services in place, you need a good network of stakeholders that can offer additional assistance.

2020 Target: - At least 2 PA management plans are developed.

OUTCOME 3 Increased area under sustainable management and increased benefits for local communities from CBWM, SFM and SLM in established CWCs

2020 TARGET: Project Board and Technical Committees meetings

Outcome 1. Increased national capacity for IWT control, and integrated wildlife and woodland management
2020 Target: - Conclude at least 2 drafts of the following acts and policies; Parks and Wildlife Act; Wildlife Policy; and the development of Human Wildlife Conflict Policy, Communal Land Forest Produce Act and the Forest Act.
Although none of the policies have yet been completed, there has been significant progress in terms of preparatory procedures, consultations, reviews and initial analyses, as follows: The process of reviewing wildlife related legislation and institutional frameworks was initiated by conducting nationwide consultations on the Wildlife Policy and the Parks and Wildlife Act. Issues of Human-Wildlife Conflict dominated most consultations. The country requires a Human-Wildlife Conflict Management Policy and this will be included in the Wildlife Policy.
2020 Target: - Facilitate training of 75 key law enforcement agencies (ZPWMA, ZRP Minerals and Border Control Unit, FC, ZIMRA, EMA, investigators, judiciary, and prosecutors) with necessary trainings and tools to fight IWT and forest crimes.
The ZPWMA conducted two trainings for rangers, one on Basic First Aid and the other on management of human-wildlife Conflict Management. The Basic First Aid training was attended by 10 rangers (6 males and 4 females), whilst 25 rangers (2 females and 23 males) attended the human-wildlife conflict management training. The extended lockdown and increasing poverty levels due to the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic negatively impacted law enforcement in the Zambezi Valley during the reporting period. The number of arrests of poachers and other offenders for environment-related crimes increased during the reporting period, and these included underage offenders. The project responded by purchasing drones, boats and increasing rations and fuel for anti-poaching activities.
2020 Target: - Involvement of 1000 beneficiaries in awareness campaign targeting IWT, deforestation and climate adaptation/mitigation issues in the project areas.
The Environmental Management Agency held 32 awareness meetings on veld fire management legislation where 2000 participants attended during the 2020 fire season in the project. In order to increase the awareness levels on dangers of veld fires, EMA also conducted 85 veld fire mobile awareness campaigns in Hurungwe, Mbire and Muzarabani District. The awareness campaigns reached out to at least 10,000 community members. The mobile awareness approach was employed as opposed to community gathering to curb the spread of COVID-19 in the project area. 14 kilometres fireguard was opened up in Muzarabani (8km) and Hurungwe (6km) districts in wards adjacent to the protected areas. Due to the efforts that were made to prepare for the fire season, there was a reduction of area burnt by 4% compared to 2019 fire season in the project area.
Outcome 2. Improved capacity of PA network and CAMPFIRE Wildlife Conservancies to protect globally significant biodiversity of the mid-lower Zambezi region over a total area of 1,616,900 ha
2020 Target: - At least 2 PA management plans are developed.
The process of hiring a consultant to develop the management plans took time. However, the project has provided funds to improve radio communication in the Zambezi Valley through enhanced communication among rangers. The ZPWMA signed a contract with PM Communications on 14 August 2020 for the supply and fixing of the radio equipment for upgrade of the Mid Zambezi Valley Radio System from analogue to digital. Full migration to the digital radio system is expected to be completed during the first third of 2021.
2020 Target: - Complete process of setting up of 3 CWCs in some districts.
The CAMPFIRE Association carried out consultations on the establishment of six Community Trusts in Mbire, Muzarabani and Hurungwe districts, and a total of 845 community members were consulted (645 men and 200 women). Community Trusts will operate in conformity with existing legislation in their interaction with government departments as well as the private sector.
OUTCOME 3 Increased area under sustainable management and increased benefits for local communities from CBWM, SFM and SLM in established CWCs
2020 Target: - Support the establishment of 3 nurseries and drilling of 14 boreholes in 3 CWCs. 78,616 seedlings were produced in 2020. The nursery at Mavhuradonha Wilderness commenced operation in the last third of the year with 14,634 seedlings being produced. Two nurseries have been fenced in the project area and boreholes will be drilled at the nurseries sites The Forestry Commission, ZPWMA and EMA carried out a joint operation to stop illegal charcoal production and firewood sales in Mbire and Muzarabani. 2058 bags of charcoal (packed in 50kg bags) and 13m3 of firewood were confiscated.
2020 Target: - Initiation of at least 6 livelihood enhancement activities through the Small Grants mechanism
The project facilitated the signing of small grant agreements between UNDP and five non-governmental organisations, namely Lower Guruve Development Association (LGDA), Southern Alliance for Indigenous Resources (SAFIRE), Environment Africa, Zim Apiculture Trust and Zambezi Society. To date US$194, 520.00 has been disbursed to support community projects under the small grants component of the project.
2020 TARGET: Project Board and Technical Committees meetings
Two board meetings were conducted in June and December 2020. The project conducted a technical committee in December to review 2020 progress as well discuss the 2020 annual report and 2021 annual work plan. The project steering/board met in December to discuss the 2020 Annual Progress Report and the 2021 Annual Workplan.

Outcome 1. OUTCOME 3 Increased area under sustainable management and increased benefits for local communities from CBWM, SFM and SLM in established CWCs 2022 Target: - 3 officially approved RBM Integrated Landscape Management Plans for target districts 2022 Target: - Support the establishment of 2 nurseries and drilling of 1 borehole in 1 CWCs. 2022 Target: - Initiation of at least 2 livelihood enhancement projects through the Small Grants mechanism OUTCOME 4 Lessons learned by the project through participatory M&E and gender mainstreaming are used nationally and internationally 2022 Target: 2 Lessons learned from the project are shared with national and international conservation programmes, including GWP
